title: 00 Guest letter
summary: December 25, 2015 letter from Don Glendenning to Premier Wade MacLauchlan inviting him as guest to "Most Likely to Succeed" screening (January 17, 2016). title: 01 Preparedness
summary: First published occasional paper examining youth preparedness gaps for employment and further study. References 2013 Community Foundation of PEI survey showing youth concerns about readiness for next life stages. Documents four public workshops (Stratford, Montague, Summerside, Wellington) where participants identified skills needed: communication, mathematics, problem-solving, personal management, teamwork, and technology comfort. Identifies preparedness gap-narrowing strategies including greater student engagement, parent-teacher communication, independent study habits, learning culture development, technology use, mentoring programs, and "can-do" school atmosphere. Makes five recommendations including further study, clearly defined graduation standards, stronger employer preparation roles, and community partnership development.

title: 08 Math Instruction In PEI
summary: This February 2021 paper addresses fragmentation in PEI mathematics education, building on the 2013 Community Foundation youth survey identifying educational deficiencies. Don analyzes multiple math providers (public schools, postsecondary institutions, SkillsPEI, private schools, independent learners) operating without coordination or shared definitions. He argues that transition from secondary to post-secondary education depends on mathematics preparation. The paper recommends adopting competency-based outcomes, implementing universal curriculum platforms, independent assessment bodies, and user-based advisory committees. Don's analysis identifies fundamental problems: lack of agreed definitions, no coordination mechanism, inconsistent evaluation criteria, and fragmented delivery. The document reflects his systematic approach to identifying systemic barriers to educational quality.

title: 09-Learning
summary: The November 15, 2013 ninth issue, edited by Don Glendenning, explores multifaceted support for learning. Don notes that effective support extends beyond teaching and telling to encompass information provision, instruction, resource materials, recognition, feedback, counsel, encouragement, and opportunity creation. He emphasizes that learners' ability to learn depends on physical, social, emotional, and mental wellness. The newsletter reports on the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island's youth survey, noting high high school and postsecondary completion rates alongside concerns about job availability, low wages, educational deficiencies, and substance abuse issues. Don highlights the survey's identification of emerging entrepreneurial opportunities and volunteerism as bright spots while flagging gaps in basic education, personal skills, and employment transition support. The issue reflects Don's comprehensive understanding of educational ecosystems and commitment to addressing barriers to learning success.

title: 1 Educational Soft spots
summary: A comprehensive essay identifying gaps and shortcomings in Canada's education system, particularly in PEI. Don critiques the rigidity of outcomes-based education (OBE), lack of school autonomy, absence of student advocates, and disconnection from job qualifications. He proposes five key reforms: updating OBE, increasing school-level autonomy, separate status for early childhood development, family education advisors, and establishing a qualification authority.
content_preview:
Educational soft spots






Education


It is widely recognized that education is a key factor in determining
one’s quality of life; in the same way, the collective education of
our citizens will determine to a significant degree the future of our
community and country. Because of this, Canada is among the world
leaders in our investment in ensuring that our citizens, especially
our youth, have access to a variety of educational activities and
experiences.  Our education system developed over decades and served
us well, however, but it is becoming rigid when the world is
demanding flexibility.  There is a gap between what Islanders have
and what they want and Islanders want to play a meaningful role in
bringing about the desired changes. 


Education
is a lifelong process of engaging in experiences that have a
formative effect on the way we feel, think and act; this effect is
usually expressed in terms of a person’s attitudes, skills and
knowledge.  Major contributors to one’s education include one’s
self, one’s home and extended family, schools and the community at
large.   Schools play a unique role in the provision of education in
that they are the only provider of educational services allowed to
award credentials, the folded paper, so esteemed by our society.


This paper


In recent months, the writer
has re-engaged in education by reading widely, conversing often, and
writing occasionally; this paper is the result.  He found  a
widespread interest in and understanding of the need for change,
agreement as to the nature of the desired system, but little
understanding among the public as to how the system works and  how to
bring about change.  Based on these discussions and the writer’s
knowledge and experience, the writer is of the view that the changes
that will make a difference are unlikely to be put in place without
some interventions from outside the system; this paper is presented

The newsletter announces a January 20, 2014 workshop at Stratford Town Hall addressing youth preparedness challenges, referencing the Community Foundation's "Taking the Pulse of Island Youth" study. Don concludes with season's greetings expressing hope for community blessings. This issue represents a culmination of Don's themes: learner-centered education, environmental support, teacher quality, and community engagement.

title: 19 news A2 Let- Getting help in Souris
summary: Letter discussing education service gaps in Souris, PEI. Don observes that while schools and counsellors serve students, no accessible resource exists for non-enrolled residents seeking education information and advice (personal development, job changes, family support, etc.). After Google searching "Souris development" and related terms, he found no integrated education resource center. Don proposes appointing an Area Coordinator through the Department of Education to ensure community-wide service delivery. This letter reflects his community-focused perspective and concern for inclusive, accessible education services beyond traditional school populations.
content_preview:
Let-2

Date

Editor




Getting help in Souris

Some time ago, I was waiting for friends at the Evergreen Restaurant in Souris when I was struck with the question as to where Souris residents obtain information and counselling on matters of education, We could ask the same question in any community.

Students can talk with teachers and counsellors but what about the people who are not in school? People may be thinking about furthering their education for many reasons: personal interest, self-development, job change or updating, to help children or grandchildren, to improve job performance, to improve quality of life in the community, and to help attract and retain businesses. Whatever the reason, where does a person or organization turn for information and advice?  

On returning home, I Googled “Souris development, Souris business development and Souris education” to see what I could find.  I used “development” as a keyword because educating is a developmental process but I also know that education is an important tool in educational development; I found schools, business development offices, career services and a few other things, but none struck me as being place where I could drop by for help.  The need for independent information and advice becomes even more important as we move more deeply into the 21st century

One solution, of course would be for the Department of Education to appoint  an area Coordinator to ensure that the people get the services they deserve; and some day when school boards find favour, to appoint a Board of Education rather than school trustees to ensure that all citizens are served not just youngsters in school







Sincerely,







Don Glendenning

A long-time student of education

BOARD RESTRUCTURING




As part of our plan to grow the Foundation, we need a strategic plan for recruitment, development and recognition of directors and committee members.  The first step, obviously, is to clarify our longer term vision of the Foundation.  While we accomplish much of that through building of endowments, our inroads into the community will come through service.




We are moving, I would say have moved, from a Level 1 community foundation to level two and have our vision set on a level three.  We should begin now to make appointments that reflect that vision.  Given your work on behalf of the Foundation, a level three operation is in sight.  




Beyond that, I am of the view that CFPEI has the potential to be the most significant player in the third sector of PEI and we need to begin positioning ourselves now for that eventuality.  To that end, I have been exploring that idea informally with a number of community leaders.  I would hope that later this spring, or at the latest early next fall, to convene a few people for the purpose of exploring this idea collectively.

Draft: March 31, 2008

COMMUNITY FOUNDATION OF PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND




Living Trust 

1. Background




Living trusts are green spaces set aside to honour, recognize, or remember a person, place or event; the key characteristic is that it is a natural space where life continues to thrive  A Living Trust may be as simple as a single tree or bush but also may be a garden, a park or a forest.  




Living Trusts are more than just a tribute; they enhance and beautify our environment, provide shelter for our wildlife, reduce erosion and improve the quality of the air we breathe.  Living trusts may bring comfort, hope and peace to visitors and ensure that generations to come will know the loveliness of a green plant.  




In addition to actual living plants and, depending on the nature of the space, green space enhancement may also include comfortable benches on which to rest, a viewing platform, path enhancement, footbridges, picnic areas, wildlife areas, handicap accessibility, and erection of shelters.  




Typical sites include schools, hospitals, municipalities, other public lands including the Confederation Trail.




2. The CFPEI Living Trust




Initial funding for The Living Trust at the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island was provided by the family of the late Dr. Charles Keuper, a retired physician who had a deep love for the natural beauty of his adopted home.  Dr. Keuper was an avid and tireless worker in the establishment of Trails PEI and a person who savoured outdoor life to the full.  Through the Living  Trust, Dr. Keuper’s family honors his memory and encourages others with similar interests to do likewise. 

The Living Trust is administered by The Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, a non-profit organization managed by a volunteer Board of Directors, which oversees permanent endowments set up by members of the community.  The purpose of the Living Memorial Trust is to make grants to enhance outdoor public green spaces throughout P...

title: 2009-13 summer Islanders
summary: Written May 29, 2009, this document evaluates CFPEI's Summer Islanders programming, including annual receptions for US citizens, summer lecture series, and social events. Don reviews the successes and challenges of each initiative, noting that the first and fourth receptions best achieved objectives with minimal resource drain and maximum opportunity for conversation. content_preview:
SD-2009-13




Date:		May 29, 2009




Subject:	The future of Summer Islanders




Background:




For a number of years now, we have been organizing activities for summer Islanders:

The purpose of the US reception is twofold: to recognize the contributions of summer islanders and to tell them about CFPEI.  The first US reception, I believe, was very successful and resulted in over 100 people enjoying a reception and entertainment at the Haviland Club.  Although I was not at the second reception, at the culinary institute, I understand that it was well attended and well received.  The third reception, also at the culinary Institute was overwhelmed by US tourists who, it seems were more attracted by the free food than by the chance to visit.  This year’s reception is by invitation only and returns to the Haviland Club.  We are designing it, hopefully, so that participants will have more opportunity to meet and visit

. 

We’ve now hosted two summer lecture series with a third planned for this year; the first two were at the Victoria Playhouse with the one this year being held at ???  In addition, we organized two summer socials, the first at UPEI and quite well attended with the second being at HMSC Charlottetown and poorly attended.




On several occasions, we’ve wondered out loud as to whether these activities were fulfilling their objectives and warrant our efforts.




Alternative ideas:




That we hand the July 4 birthday celebration over to the various municipalities and suggest that it be public, with national anthems and birthday cake only

That we develop a “Summer Islanders Society” as an instrument to help Summer Islanders learn more about the Island, to meet and get to know other Islanders and to encourage them to contribute even more than they have in the past.  I am suggesting a fee which we would use to help with organization costs.

As non-profit  organizations play increasingly important roles in our society, it becomes even more critical for them to perform effectively.   Staff, volunteers and Board members of Non-governmental Organizations are showing a growing interest in practices and principles that will help them build high-performing mission-driven organizations, rather than just stronger programs. Nursing Scholarships go Begging




Scholarships worth four thousand dollars for nurses in their third or fourth year of training in any Canadian university have not received a single application.  The scholarships, one at the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island (CFPEI) and the other at the Eastern Kings Health Foundation, are valued at $2,000 each and are for students in training who agree to accept employment at the Souris hospital for one or  two years after graduation.  Time is running out and, unless applications are received soon, it will be too late for this year.




While on the Island during the summer of 2007, Rear Admiral Louise C and James Wilmot, an American couple and long time summer residents of the Island, approached the Community Foundation with a view to establishing a nursing scholarship.  Don Glendenning, on behalf of CFPEI, brokered an arrangement with the Eastern Kings Health Foundation who decided to match the Wilmot’s offer.




In commenting on the Wilmot scholarship, Dr. Glendenning, Past President of the CFPEI, thanked the Wilmot’s and the Eastern Kings Health Foundation for their financial support to make the scholarship a reality and added “The establishment of these scholarships is a classic example of the role of a community foundation, linking people who care with causes that matter.”

COMMUNITY BUILDERS LEGACY FUND







WHAT IS A COMMUNITY BUILDER?




Community Builders are people who are interested in making Prince Edward Island an even better place to live – both for this generation and generations to follow.  Community builders want to give back to their community and want to start doing now.  Community builders are thinkers, planners, and doers in all walks of life.  They realize that their successes resulted from help by many people and, through establishing a legacy fund; they can say thanks while making the community a better place for others.




WHAT DO COMMUNITY BUILDERS DO?




Community Builders can be recognized by what they do, even though all community builders do not do the same thing.  Some build quietly and out of sight, others build publicly; most have a passion whether for the environment, heritage, education, health, religion, or the general welfare of friends and neighbours.  They are active in volunteering, contributing, leading, supporting and giving.  They help out today but also think about tomorrow.  They also set aside funds to support their passions even when they are no longer here to do so.







WHAT IS A LEGACY FUND?




A Legacy Fund is an endowment the income from which is available in perpetuity to support good works and causes identified by the community builder.  Such endowments may be created at the time of death; however, increasingly community builders participate in both the planning and building of an endowment while they are still alive.  In this way, they can participate in the design of their legacy and the decision-making as to which causes gifts may be given.  Community builders also may, if they so desire, continue as advisors to their investments even after assigning ownership to CFPEI.

title: 2013-08 School Board elections
summary: Supporting school board elections as engagement indicators, Don cites National Parent Teacher Association research confirming that family-school-community collaboration improves student achievement, teacher morale, and communication. Addressing concerns about low voter interest, Don suggests public apathy reflects perception of trustee powerlessness rather than disinterest. Empowering trustees with real decision-making authority would likely increase engagement. The letter positions community involvement as a policy lever rather than an isolated governance matter.
content_preview:
May 13, 2013




Editor, Charlottetown Guardian

Charlottetown, PEI	




Dear Sir:

School board elections




I support the idea of school board elections because they are an indicator of school engagement, and students do better in schools where communities are involved.  The National Parent Teacher Association in the USA reports that “when families, schools, and communities work together,

Student achievement improves,

Teacher morale rises,

Communication increases” 




As for low voter interest and turnout, it may simply be a reflection of a public perception that trustees have little authority to make decisions that count; public apathy may be better countered by giving trustees real decision-making authority.   

Join the discussion and send me a note at  HYPERLINK "mailto:standards2020@gmail.com" standards2020@gmail.com 

Sincerely

Don Glendenning

A long-time student of education

the

Medicine Hat Legacy Club
        
Created in 2005 (Alberta's Centennial Year) the Legacy Club provides an opportunity for everyone to create and build their own community legacy,
        
The Legacy Club runs each year and is simple, unique and lasting.  A Legacy Club membership can commence with as little as $500 received by December 31st.  
        
Legacy donations are placed in an endowment fund in the chosen name of the donor.  For example it could be a family or business name or perhaps it could named in memory of a loved one.  Your fund is pooled together with other donations and invested.  The interest is then used to make grants to local Southeastern Alberta charities.  The original gift is never touched and becomes a never ending source of income for the community - a true legacy. 
        
The type of endowment can be chosen depending on the size of the gift as follows:
        
Pledged Fund   (minimum $500)
        
Allows a named fund of any category to be created.  A pledged fund requires regular contributions until the desired amount is achieved.  No disbursements are made until a minimum of $1,000 is reached.
        
Community Fund (minimum $1.000)
        
Large and small gifts are combined and the income is distributed through a grant application process.  This fund ensures that the changing needs of the community are addressed in a timely manner.

You choose a favourite registered charity and the income from your fund is distributed to that charity in your name every year.

title: Barbara McInnis
summary: Letter dated August 14, 2007, from Don Glendenning to Barbara McInnis addressing her book on community foundations. Don provides thoughtful observations on asset-building challenges in small communities, out-migration of young entrepreneurs, and competitive fundraising landscape dominated by universities, hospitals, and cultural institutions. He emphasizes community foundations' overlooked leadership role in convening stakeholders to solve problems and advocates for viewing them as essential community infrastructure. References his international development experience and explores how community foundations might serve international development contexts.
content_preview:
Date:		August 14, 2007




To:		Barbara McInnis




From:		Don Glendenning




Subject:	Community foundations




Greetings from Prince Edward Island.




I am not sure that I have any observations of value when writing your book but here are a few comments: 




First let me point out some of the unique problems of asset building in a small community and small province.  It is likely that many of this same problems exist in other remote communities in this country and countries as well.




Headquarters for many of potential corporate donors/sponsors are most often located in another Province not just another part of the Province.  The larger the company the more likely that its headquarters is Montreal, Toronto or Vancouver.  It is not easy, and sometimes expensive, to meet the decision-makers.  

We have a large out migration of young  people, therefore, many of our successful young entrepreneurs do not live on PEI.

On the other hand, contacting and convening key decision-makers or stakeholders is, I believe, easier to accomplish.

In the case of PEI, the big four in fund raising are the University, two hospitals and the Confederation Centre.  While we have cordial relations with all, we have not found a way yet to partner in a significant common venture.




With regard to your specific questions:




I’d like to see more emphasis on the leadership role of community foundations.  We underestimate the importance of our non-monetary contributions.  The process of convening stakeholders to solve problems has tremendous potential.  The issue of asset development versus leadership/liaison poses a dilemma.  A community foundation needs an endowment to address local needs (make strategic grants), at the same time, many important contributions can be made by convening stakeholders. 

 

Community foundations should be viewed as part of the infrastructure of a community.  Like a highway, a power line, a bank or a telephone system, a community foundation is a mechanism f...

Claude and Bernice Bell

Dear:




Recently the media reported the results of a survey by the Dominion Institute as to the state of teaching of Canadian history in our schools.  The release of the report triggered a couple of editorials and a number of letters in the local media and, while the Dominion Institute report spoke only about the public schools, the issue really reaches beyond the school system..




We, the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, wondered if we had a role to play in this issue.  Given our motto, connecting people who care with causes that matter, we answered “Yes”; and as with any other issue, we provide a vehicle to help make change happen.




Consequently, CFPEI proposes a Canada History Fund (Canada Fund?) for the purpose of promoting and encouraging the study of Canadian history.  The Fund could be used for any purpose that promotes the learning of Canadian history including school based activities but also, lectures, debates, forums, events and the purchase or preparation of learning materials.  Our goal for the fund is $100,000 which can be made up through a combination of named and unnamed endowments and flow-through donations.




This is a follow-up to earlier conversations about a fund in your names at the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island as part of your legacy and wonder if a fund for the promotion of Canadian history would be of interest.  If interested, I would be pleased to discuss the idea further with you.




Warm personal regards




Don Glendenning

Director

BOARD RESTRUCTURING




As part of our plan to grow the Foundation, we need a strategic plan for recruitment, development and recognition of directors and committee members.  The first step, obviously, is to clarify our longer term vision of the Foundation.  While we accomplish much of that through building of endowments, our inroads into the community will come through service.




We are moving, I would say have moved, from a Level 1 community foundation to level two and have our vision set on a level three.  We should begin now to make appointments that reflect that vision.  Given your work on behalf of the Foundation, a level three operation is in sight.  




Beyond that, I am of the view that CFPEI has the potential to be the most significant player in the third sector of PEI and we need to begin positioning ourselves now for that eventuality.  To that end, I have been exploring that idea informally with a number of community leaders.  I would hope that later this spring, or at the latest early next fall, to convene a few people for the purpose of exploring this idea collectively.  




I have been thinking about the future of CFPEI, browsing some foundation websites and reflecting on our own operation and various discussions.  Here are some ideas for your consideration 




Board Recruitment.

     

Fundy Foundation has a board Recruitment Committee consisting of six members including two current directors; the chair of that committee is external.  Both Moncton and the Nova Community Foundation, I believe, still have external nominating committees.  Such an approach, I believe, keeps the "ownership" with the community.




If this is of interest, one approach would be to establish a three person committee consisting of (1) a recent appointee to the Order of Canada and (2) a recent appointee to the Order of PEI and (3) a member of the Board.  I like the idea of an external chair although I realize that having a board member as chair is more efficient.

This letter comes to introduce you to the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island and to seek an opportunity to discuss the services we offer.  While the Foundation may not be well-known, we have been making grants to organizations in the Souris area for a number of years. Margaret Ching is a past Director, Carol Fraser is a current Director and John and Pam  MacDonald are very much aware of our activities.  




Most people support a number of charitable organizations and activities.  When it comes their charitable legacy, however, more and more are choosing their local community foundation; they do so for the following reasons:




Community foundations, focus on the long-term future of their communities, engage in the building of endowments and allow donors to keep their charitable funds intact enabling them to support the causes and organizations of their choice.

Community foundations have a community orientation rather than a focus on a single charitable issue.  Their goal is to improve the lives of individuals and their communities.  This is accomplished by making grants for the purposes, and only the purposes, designated by individual donors.    This results in increasing the value of their contributions to community causes.

Community foundations allow us to keep our charitable legacy in a single location thereby keeping the legacy intact and flowing grants to the individual charities of interest on a regular basis and in perpetuity..  Traditionally, donors make separate donations to each organization they wish to support; unfortunately, that approach results in the legacy being dispersed; in addition, not all charitable organizations are in a position to handle endowments effectively. Adding Value to our Communities




Background




The Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island (CFPEI) was incorporated in 1993 and has a Revenue Canada charitable tax number (89001 1190 RR 001) and a charitable tax number for the USA. ( 30-0050801).  CFPEI is one of 140 community foundations in Canada.  It has a Provincial mandate and is governed by 12 Directors from across the Province who are representative of the Island community.  The Foundation is committed to enhancing the quality of life in Prince Edward Island and operates with maximum transparency and public accountability.  




Community foundations provide an infrastructure for people with many different charitable interests to make long-term contributions to their communities through the establishment of endowments.  Foundations solicit and accept charitable gifts for the purpose of establishing endowments, pool the funds for investment and management purposes, and make grants, which reflect the wishes of the donors.  A second major focus is to provide leadership and support to other charitable organizations.  It is the latter issue for which a more detailed proposal is being developed.

	outlets limit themselves to one line of service or product.  For
	example, Canadian Tire carries clothes, grocery stores have
	pharmacies, stationary stores carry computers, computer stores carry
	kitchen appliances, and service stations are convenience stores.  
	
	



	
	
Charitable
	organizations generally cater to specific charitable interests, such
	as a church, a hospital, school, a special community project, etc. A
	charitable organization raises funds and makes grants only for that
	purpose.
	



	
	
Community
	foundations, on the other hand, are multi-purpose.  They focus on
	the well being of a community whether the need, or challenge, be
	social, educational, environmental, religious or cultural.  Donors
	no longer have to shop for a worthy cause; they simply articulate
	their charitable wishes and let a community foundation carry them
	out.  And because of the breadth of community contacts and
	experience, community foundations can provide useful advice about
	both community needs and opportunities.  
	
	



	
	



	
	
Through
	the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, a donor can:
	



	
	
		

Set
		up a scholarship for a student in high school, university, college
		or any other educational institution on PEI or elsewhere.
		

Set
		up an endowment to remember a family, family member or friend.
		

Honour
		a colleague or community volunteer.
		

Make
		a memorial contribution.
		

Establish
		a legacy now or through a will that continues support to a charity
		of the donor’s choice into the future. ...

title: CFPEI 54-Imagine
summary: This October 2006 newsletter addresses misconceptions about endowments, explaining that they need not require large sums and can be built over time. Don provides concrete examples: $1,000 annually for five years generates $200 perpetual grants, life insurance policies offer tax deductions, and stock donations save taxes. He emphasizes CFPEI's accessibility and volunteer-managed board of PEI-based directors, promoting the foundation's one-percent annual administration fee as unbeatable. This educational approach demonstrates Don's commitment to democratizing philanthropy and making charitable giving accessible to islanders of modest means, reflecting his leadership philosophy at Holland College and beyond.

title: CFPEI 59-Changing the face of charity
summary: This January 2006 newsletter provides strategic analysis of community foundations' role in reshaping Canada's charitable sector. Don features CFPEI President Norman Carruthers explaining how community foundations differ from traditional charities by addressing broad community needs across all sectors. He details CFPEI's impact: a $100,000 Challenge Grant to 50 organizations for capacity building, scholarship programs, and emergency response initiatives. Don emphasizes donors' growing desire to customize donations and the foundation's flexibility in responding to varied charitable interests (literacy, medical emergencies, scholarships, area-specific funds). The low one-percent administration fee is highlighted as enabling donor accessibility.
content_preview:
Community Foundation News



           



No. 59						                   January 26, 2006


Reshaping
	the charitable sector
	



	
	
Community
	foundations have reshaped the charitable sector across Canada and
	the effects are being felt in Prince Edward Island.  So says Norman
	Carruthers, President of the Community Foundation of Prince Edward
	Island.
	



	
	
Most
	charitable organizations are focused on the needs of a particular
	segment of the community such as health, the local hospital, or the
	local arts organization.  Community foundations, on the other hand,
	have a broad interest in all of the needs of all of the communities
	across the Island whether those needs be in the field of health,
	education, religion, environment, heritage, arts or any other
	sector.  In accomplishing their mandate, community foundations
	support charitable organizations that work in any and all sectors.  
	
	



	
	
To
	illustrate the point, under a recent “Challenge Grant”, the
	Foundation made grants totaling $100,000 to some 50 PEI charitable
	organizations in the area of capacity building.  In addition, the
	Foundation offered scholarships and conducted a number of workshops
	for the charitable sector.
	



	
	
Perhaps
	a greater impact, however, has come from the Foundations ability to
	respond to donors’ interests in customizing their donations. 
	Regardless of the charitable interest, community foundations can
	find ways to respond.  As examples, thanks to the generosity of
	donors, grants are now available to improve the first response
	efforts to medical emergencies, to purchase books for Island
	schools, to support literacy and to provide scholarships for PEI
	students who wish to study either on or off the Island.  The Souris
	Fund is another example of our flexibility in that it provides

title: CFPEI 67 Agriculture Heritage
summary: May 2007 newsletter documenting a multi-year agricultural heritage project preserving PEI-made farm equipment. The initiative included Tony Glencross's initial survey, McNaught History Centre's "Made in PEI" report, donations to PEI Museum and Heritage Foundation (including a Hall thresher with original owner's production logs), and museum discussions about inventory and preservation. Conclusions identified storage space needs, significant undocumented island-made equipment, continuing inventory requirements, collector networking desires, and conservation assistance gaps. The fund promotion and network development demonstrate Don's commitment to cultural heritage preservation and community institution building.

title: CFPEI 83 Growing your legacy
summary: Newsletter No. 83 from March 29, 2008, presents Don's philosophical reflections on legacy planning and endowments. Opening with a farmer's parable about persistently moving a stone through repeated effort, Don draws parallels to building personal wealth and community legacies. He contrasts temporary donations with permanent endowments, emphasizing how legacy funds continue supporting causes after donors' deaths. The newsletter encourages people to establish endowments reflecting their interests, describing CFPEI's experience in administering such funds and its commitment to honoring donor intentions over time. This piece reveals Don's thoughtful approach to philanthropy and estate planning.
content_preview:
Community Foundation News



           



No.  83					              	         March 29, 2008


	


	
	
From
	Little Acorns…
	



	
	
A
	farmer pastured his cows in the back field.  In the corner of the
	field was a large flat stone that he wanted for a front step at his
	new home – but he did not have the means to load it on to the
	wagon.  So, each morning when taking the cows to the pasture and
	evening when bringing them home, he reached under one edge of the
	stone and, with a mighty heave, flipped it over once in the
	direction of home. Before the snow blanketed his yard, his home
	sported a beautiful natural stone step – a step that would be
	cherished by in his family for generations to come.
	



	
	
We
	invest in our future in much the same way, one step at a time - a
	few dollars at a time through buying a bond, buying a home,
	purchasing a bit of real estate, adding to our savings account,
	purchasing stocks, paying off a mortgage, etc.  
	
	



	
	
As
	we think of divestment, our first obligation is to provide for
	ourselves and our families.  The concept of a rainy day fund is
	replaced by the idea of a legacy fund.  Legacy funds continue
	support for cherished causes or organizations; legacy funds involve
	giving generously to the community that gave generously to us.  
	
	



	
	
A
	legacy fund is different from just making a donation; a legacy fund
	keeps on supporting causes that matter to you when you are no longer
	available to provide that support personally.  
	
	



	
	
Instead
	of, or in addition to, writing a cheque today or a bequest in a
	will, you are encouraged to establish an endowment.  If structured
	properly, your favourite charity will receive income in your name
	for years to come and your contribution, instead of being used up,
	will continue to grow in value.

	Foundation of Prince Edward Island is experienced in setting up
	legacy funds; funds that reflect the interest of people just like

The document outlines five grant purposes focused on building community capacity, developing local leadership, improving resource use, encouraging collaboration, and strengthening voluntary sector organizations. Detailed decision-making criteria address issues like inclusiveness, governance quality, partnership building, innovation, and community benefit. Funding restrictions exclude debt retirement, deficit reduction, computer equipment, sports sponsorships, individuals, core operations, single-religion support, and retroactive expenses. This comprehensive policy document, edited by Don, reflects the Foundation's mature operational framework and commitment to strategic grantmaking.

	A Brief History

title: CFPEI tribute to Robinson
summary: A tribute to John Robinson celebrating his leadership of the Community Foundation of PEI, which grew assets from $1 million to $7 million under his direction. Don credits Robinson's vision of the Foundation as key provincial infrastructure and praises his engagement of summer residents and development of investment policies. content_preview:
:

John Robinson

John Robinson first came to my attention during a conversation with Tom Davies, then President of the Community Foundation, as a possible board member and future president. Tom was right; John was  both of these   and more and became a driving force behind the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island.  

I’ve known John for 20 years, first as a successful Island business man and entrepreneur, a man, well known in the agriculture industry for progressive farming practices, leadership in the sector and stewardship of the land.  While his business was farming, his interests included the agricultural sector and the Island as a whole.  The Robinson family was, and still is, active in their church, supporters of community organizations and events, and play leadership roles in many areas especially in supporting arts and culture. 

John was elected Director of the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island in 1999 and soon adopted a proprietary interest in its future, served wherever help was needed, including three terms as President.  In the early years of the Foundation, John led the Foundation in the establishment of sound investment policies and business practices.  John recognized PEI summer visitors as significant contributors to PEI life, especially to our arts and culture, and took steps to engage them in summer activities, most notably a reception on July 4 for US visitors and a summer lecture series so that guests could get to know the Island he loved.  Not surprising, John also registered the Community Foundation with the US internal Revenue Service so that US donors to island charitable causes could claim donations to the Foundation on their US income tax returns

John is currently leading the Foundation efforts in the area of development; he sees the Foundation as a key component of the provinces infrastructure, a component committed to building a pool of funds to be available in perpetuity for the betterment of the Island community – ...

I write, Cindy, to introduce the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island and to offer our services should you be thinking of establishing a memorial in your Dad’s memory.  Your Dad was aware of the work of the foundation and made a contribution to one of our early initiatives.




First some comments about community foundations in general and the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island in particular.




Community foundations, and there are 170 in Canada today, create and administer permanent endowments for charitable purposes.  The goal is to improve the lives of individuals and their communities.  This is accomplished by making grants for the purposes, and only the purposes, designated by individual donors.   Funds from donors are pooled and invested in perpetuity; earnings are used to make grants.  

The Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island serves the entire Province, is governed by a volunteer board widely representative of Island life, maintains an office in Charlottetown, has assets approaching $1.5 million, makes grants annually in excess of $50,000, is being used increasingly by Islanders to host their charitable legacies, is registered with both the Canada Revenue  Agency and the IRS,  is transparent and open while following sound business practices.

Investments are professionally managed, books are audited annually and reports are public.  Although one of the newer community foundations in Canada, we are well experienced in creating and administering  endowments (over 60 at the moment) for the  benefit of Island organizations and individuals. .

(Name of Partner) Community Challenge Program







Background	Most charitable giving is focused on meeting immediate needs and for specific causes.  Reflection and informal consultation indicates a parallel need to develop longer term plan and resources in the charitable sector at the community level and not to be solely dependent upon the efforts of particular interest groups regardless of how relevant and important such initiatives may be. 




	With this view in mind, CFPEI pr5oposes a Community Challenge Program to encourage communities, not just organizations, to build resources to meet future anticipated an unanticipated community needs.

Dear Mr. Gregory:

Community Advancement Program




This is a follow-up to our discussion of Wednesday, June 7, regarding your potential interest in the proposed Community Advancement Program.  




First a brief background on the Foundation.  The Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island is a not-for-profit organization established in 1993 for the purpose of improving the quality of life in our Island community.  The Foundation achieves this objective by encouraging Islanders, Island organizations and communities, to establish endowments from which grants are made out of the earnings in support of the charitable interests of the donor.  The Foundation administers the funds and ensures that the grants are made for the purposes intended.  The Foundation is governed by a board of 12 Directors from across the Island.




In practice, The Foundation carries out four functions:

Informing Islanders of needs and opportunities and assisting them in designing charitable responses to match their interests and resources.

Providing a liaison and coordination role with individuals and organizations engaged in charitable work.

Making grants to reflect donors wishes.

Administering CFPEI including investing funds.

The building of an endowment in excess of $750.000 in some 25 separate funds.

title: Dear Hesta
summary: Letter dated March 20, 2007, from Don Glendenning to Dr. Hesta MacDonald responding to her interest in establishing a charitable legacy through a foundation. Don provides comprehensive background on community foundations, including Canadian history (first founded Winnipeg 1921, now 155 across Canada with $2.7 billion in assets), governance structure, and advantages of establishing funds within CFPEI rather than private foundations. Describes different fund types (undesignated, designated, interest) and their flexibility. References the Winnipeg Foundation's $100 million Richardson donation and international examples of family foundations transitioning to community foundation funds. Includes CFPEI fact sheet and draft interest agreement. Exemplifies Don's educational and advisory role in promoting community foundation philanthropy.
content_preview:
March 20, 2007




Dr. Hesta MacDonald

206 Spring Park Road

Charlottetown, 

PE	C1A 3Y9




Dear Dr. MacDonald:




As usual, I enjoyed our coffee last week; it was also great to see so many former colleagues and continuing friends.




You mentioned your interest in setting up a “foundation” to carry on your charitable interests into the future.  I think that is appropriate.  Doing so, also relieves you and your family, of both the administration and cost of establishing a private foundation. 




As you know, I have been active in the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island for the last two decades and am pleased to provide a few brief comments about community foundations for your consideration:




The principal business of a community foundation is to establish, build and administer charitable trusts.

The first Community Foundation in Canada was established in Winnipeg in 1921; today there are 155 community foundations across the country with assets of $2.7 billion.  Community foundations piloted the model which, during the last few years, financial institutions are now adopting and adapting.

Community foundations are directed by Boards of Directors made up of local community leaders with an interest in their community and who see community foundations as a simple, flexible, transparent, accountable and inexpensive approach enabling people to contribute to their communities in perpetuity.

Community Foundation administrative fees are similar across the country and, I believe, are the lowest of any in the private or charitable sector.  Our investment fees, for example, are .7 of one percent and our administration fee is one percent.   The total annual fee at CFPEI for $100,000 endowment would be $1,700 and includes the investment an administration of the funds, an annual audit, and the operation of the office, soliciting applications and making grants, the preparation of an annual report and convening of an open public annual meeting.

title: Elizabeth Reagh 2011 03 09
summary: Personal letter from Don Glendenning to Elizabeth Reagh (March 9, 2011) discussing legacy planning. Summarizes CFPEI credentials: 170+ community foundations in Canada, professional investment management, annual audits, transparent reporting, and experience administering 50+ endowments. Explains advantages of community foundation vehicles: low-cost alternatives to direct disbursements, perpetual income generation, and flexibility. Describes specific fund structures: Host Organization Funds (organizations entrustfunds for investment with access to accumulated income) and Agency Funds (charitable organizations establish permanent funds for ongoing program support). Offers free consultation and plans follow-up meeting.

Ms. Elizabeth Reagh

17 West Street

Charlottetown, PEI

C1A 3S3




Dear Elizabeth,




Enjoyed our conversation of the other day and appreciate your interest in discussing with the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island the services it offers.  I know that we have spoken about the Community Foundation but thought I would provide you with a few key points 




The Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island serves the entire Province, is governed by a volunteer board widely representative of Island life, maintains an office in Charlottetown, has assets approaching $1.5 million, makes grants annually in excess of $70,000, is being used increasingly by Islanders to host their charitable legacies, is registered with both the Canada Revenue Agency and the IRS, and is transparent and open while following sound business practices.

Investments are professionally managed, books are audited annually and reports are public.  Although one of the newer community foundations in Canada, we are well experienced in creating and administering  endowments (over 50 at the moment) for the  benefit of Island organizations and individuals. 

When it comes to their charitable legacy, more and more are choosing their local community foundation; they do so for the following reasons:

Community foundations provide a vehicle for people to create named permanent endowment funds to support their charitable causes and interests.  Funds are invested in perpetuity, and the earnings are used to make grants on an ongoing basis for the charitable causes and interests they designate. By pooling many individual endowment funds for administration and investment purposes, community foundations are able to minimize the cost of their services and maximize the return on their investments, thus maximizing the amount available for granting.

content_preview:
November 19, 2007




COMMUNITY FOUNDATION OF PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND




Living Memorial Trusts




1. Background




Living memorials are green spaces set aside in memory of a person, place or event; the key characteristic is that it is a natural space and plant life continues to grow.   A living memorial may be as simple as a single tree or bush but also may be a garden, a park or a forest.  




Living Memorials are more than just a tribute to loved ones; living memorials enhance and beautify our environment, provide shelter for our wildlife, reduce erosion and improve the quality of the air we breathe.  Living memorials may bring comfort, hope and peace to visitors and ensure that generations to come will know the beauty of a green plant.  




In addition to actual living plants and, depending on the nature of the space , a living memorial may also include comfortable benches on which to rest, a scenic view or viewing platform, path enhancement, footbridges, picnic areas, wildlife areas, handicap accessibility, and erection of shelters.  




2. Why a living memorial?




People usually donate to a Living Memorial to recognize or honour a person, organization or event at a time of a major life change including:




a special birthday, 

a retirement,

the birth of a child,

the death of a family member, friend or colleague,

recognition of long and loyal service,

recognition of outstanding service

the relocation of a colleague or friend







3. The CFPEI Living Memorial Trust




Initial funding for The Living Memorial Trust at the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island was provided by the family of Dr. Charles Keuper, a retired physician with a deep love for the natural beauty of his adopted home.  Dr. Keuper was an avid and tireless worker in the establishment of Trails PEI and a person who savoured outdoor life to the full.  Through the Living Memorial Trust, Dr. Keuper’s family honors his memory and encourages others with similar interests to do lik...

Dear Mr. Heim:




I was delighted with your telephone call about the Hall and Stavert casting in your possession.  Please excuse the delay in getting back to you.  




As I mentioned, my father and Harold Hall went into the foundry business together in 1933.  The castings in your possession would have been one of their items but I do not know how many would have been cast. Hall and Stavert is still operating but now we produce mostly marine propellers.  




The wheels, we think, would have been cast about 1940.  We certainly do not have any original casting is and I am not aware of any in our local museums but I do not know for sure.  One wonders how such an item ever reached Illinois. 




I do not recall just how many of the Hall and Stavert castings you have in your possession, but if more than one, I and am wondering if you would have any interest in seeing one or more of the castings returned to PEI.




Thanks again for getting in touch.




Compliments of the season.




Jim Stavert

content_preview:
Hugh Black

London, Ontario

This is a follow up to an earlier reference about a legacy fund  honouring Roger’s life and contributions to Prince Edward Island. 

Roger spent most of his working life in the Maritimes, first at Dalhousie University and, since 1968, in Prince Edward Island.  Recently his friend and mentor, Henry Purdy, and I reminisced over coffee about Roger and an appropriate legacy.  Here are some ideas arising from that conversation.

  
Certainly the top of our list is Roger’s his interest in art, especially emerging artists and most notably the work of students.  Roger was a fixture at all student art shows and seldom left without purchasing at least one or more pieces.  We also know that he purchased pieces from other new and emerging Island artists.  This interest could be continued in a number of ways such as an sponsorship of an annual student art show, awards, or even  a fund future pieces for the Island art collection.
  
Roger was recognized by the community as a knowledgeable and astute investor.  In fact, for a number of years he was a part-time lecturer in personal investment at Holland College..  That legacy could be remembered through a sponsorship of investment clubs for Island youth with with an annual award for the most successful team.
  
Roger was a regular contributor to the Queen Elizabeth Hospital, the Island’s major acute care hospital.  For a number of years he was also a regular contributor to the Confederation Centre of the Arts.  These contributions could be continued through the Prof. R.D.H. Black Endowment with the Community Foundation of Prince Edward island.


If you have an interest, Hugh, in establishing a legacy in Roger’s name, I would be pleased to work with Henry Purdy in putting together a proposal for your consideration.

If I can be of any service in this or any other way, please do not hesitate to let me know.




Sincerely




Don Glendenning

title: Launch -Letter to Keuper Friends
summary: Formal letter from Norman Carruthers, President of Community Foundation of PEI, to friends of Dr. Charles Keuper announcing the establishment of a Living Memorial Trust endowment. Explains the trust's purpose to honor Keuper's legacy of preserving PEI's natural beauty and heritage. Describes initial tree planting at Trails PEI entrance in Wood Islands where Keupers first settled. Includes donation information and enclosed brochure. Shows collaborative effort between Keuper family, Foundation, and Glendenning.
content_preview:
Dear




As a friend of Dr. Charles Keuper, you will know that he loved Prince Edward Island and worked diligently for the preservation of its beauty and heritage.




To continue his work and to honour his name, the Keuper family established a Living Memorial Trust at the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island.  The Trust is in the form of an endowment and will provide grants in perpetuity for the enhancement of public spaces.




While funds may be used for any public space, The Foundation decided as a first priority, to plant trees at a number of entrances to Trails PEI, a network of walking trails based on the original railway lines.  Recent years has seen Trails PEI assume an increasing importance in the life of Islanders and visitors alike. 




To launch the Living Memorial Trust, and in recognition of the life of Dr. Keuper, a cluster of native red oak trees was planted at the Trail entrance in Wood Islands, the community in which the Keupers first settled when they moved to PEI.  Dr. Keuper’s son, John and his family, still live and carries on a horticultural business in the community.




We are delighted to share this information with you and to include a newspaper clipping of the official launch.  The Living Memorial Trust is also described in the enclosed brochure together with a donation form should you want to make a donation in his memory.  The Foundation has both a US and Canadian charitable tax number.




Should you desire more information about the Living Memorial Trust or the Community Foundation, do not hesitate to let us know.




Sincerely







Norman Carruthers

President

title: Launch-Press Release
summary: Official press release announcing the establishment of the Living Memorial Trust by Community Foundation of PEI. Details inaugural planting of native red oak trees at Wood Islands Trails PEI entrance in memory of Dr. Charles Keuper. Provides biographical information on Keuper (Texas physician, Harvard Medical School teacher, retired to PEI in 1979). Explains benefits of living memorials and solicits contributions. Attributes initial funding to Keuper family and lists contact information for Don Glendenning and Foundation office.
content_preview:
Draft Press Release for July 21, 2007




Living Memorial Trust Established




The Wood Islands entrance to Trails PEI looks different today, and will be significantly different in 20 years, thanks to the planting of two clusters of native red oak trees.  The planting is the first initiative of the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island under the newly established Living Memorial Trust from which grants will be made for the purpose of enhancing public spaces throughout Prince Edward Island.




The Living Memorial Trust was established through the efforts of the Keuper Family to remember the life of Dr. Charles Keuper, a physician who came to PEI after retirement in 1979 and worked tirelessly to protect and enhance the Island’s natural beauty.  Dr. Keuper was born in Schulenburg, Texas, received his higher education at Elmhurst College, Illinois and the University of Texas.  After a stint as a Medical Officer with the United States Army in Japan, Dr. Keuper opened a practice in Boston and taught for a number of years at Harvard Medical School.  Upon retirement, the Keuper family set up residence in Wood Islands.  




Living Memorials are more than just a tribute; living memorials enhance and beautify our environment, provide shelter for wild life, reduce erosion and improve the quality of the air we breathe.  Grants may be made for the enhancement of any public space, however, the initial focus will be on trail entrances.  Contributions to The Living Memorial Trust are welcomed to mark a milestone in the life of a person or organization and all donations will be recorded in a Memorial Register.  Individual interested in plantings in places of special significance should contact the Foundation.  Donors will be given a receipt to be used when filing Income Tax returns in Canada or the USA 




Persons interested in learning more about, or contributing to the Living Memorial Trust, may do so by contacting the Community Foundation office, 892-3440..

title: Literacy letter Callbeck
summary: An October 26, 2009 letter from Don to Catherine Callbeck highlighting the Community Foundation's commitment to literacy issues and proposing an initiative to convene literacy stakeholders for dialogue. Don notes that despite a year of conversations and Foundation grant-making to home literacy projects, the fundamental problem remains: literacy providers operate in isolation without coordination. October 26, 2009




Hon. Catherine Callbeck

Bedeque

PEI		C0B 1C0

Canada







Dear Senator Callbeck:







 About a year ago we spoke on a number occasions about the importance of literacy and the need for training.  




Since then, I have had a number of discussions with others on the subject and the Foundation has made a grant to the Summerside Home and School Association to assist in their project to encourage new mothers to read to their children.




Recently, the Board of Governors held a discussion as to community needs with literacy training was identified one of the priorities.  In fact, the Foundation has invited Barbara McNutt, Coordinator of Literacy Training, to address the issue at our next meeting.  




One of the problems with the current arrangements is that the various delivering agencies operate in isolation from each other.  It is time, I suggest, to engage stakeholders (those who need, provide and pay for) in dialogue about the issue.  Out of the dialogue should come greater coordination if not cooperation?  Hopefully, also, we will identify key people to lead the initiative in the longer run 




Initiating dialogue will require a small amount of funding (copying, mailing, meeting space, perhaps for travel  from outside the Charlottetown area, etc.  Given our earlier conversation, I am wondering if you would be prepared to help.  Because I believe strongly in the need, I am prepared, Catherine, to give this initiative some personal attention.

About math-3

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

DEFINITIONS: 

Education – any experience that has a formative effect on the way a person thinks, feels or acts

Mathematics – the study of science of number, quantity, and space.

Math education – the extent and nature of a person’s attitudes, skills an knowledge in and about the field of math.

Relevance - 




EDUCATION

Our futures and the future of our community will depend in large measure on the nature and level of education gained by our citizens. Provinces have a responsibility to help their citizens develop attitudes, skills and knowledge at least to the level of good citizenship;  Provinces also have a responsibility to ensure that their communities have the skilled people, including skills in math,  needed to care for the community in which they live.   A 2003 multi-country study by the European Commission found that, if the national average educational attain-ment level is increased by a single year, aggregate productivity increases by 6.2 per cent right away and by a further 3.1 per cent in the long run.




Education is offered through a public-school system devoted to serving the needs of young people, a number of relatively autonomous postsecondary institutions, the private sector and a conglomeration of services operated or administered through provincial ministries of learning, training and workforce development (much of the latter is paid for by federal dollars).  Public and media comment sugges, hover, gap however, between what education offers and what the community expects.  The Council of Ministers of Education Canada (CMEC) highlighted this concern in its statement of July 6. 2016 when it said the need to improve transition is shared by many educators, employers, certification agencies and the community at large.

The release emphasizes foundations in home and K-12 education, proposes an independent qualification authority for consistency across the province, and suggests documentation of skills learned on the job. Other ideas include short technical courses (three months), vouchers, competency lists for job seekers, and institutional cooperation. Don Glendenning is listed as contact.
content_preview:
_____________________________________________________________________________


For immediate release

Skill
development needs a context






The
meaning of skill development is not clear; at least that was the view
of participants at a recent workshop on the subject.  After some
discussion the group settled on “increasing one’s skill to do
“something”. That “something” could be citizenship,
employment, further study or for all three, but it needs to be clear.
 Furthermore, the foundation
for skills development lies in the home and the K-12 education system
and Successful skill development programs require a high level of
communication between all parties involved.






As
well as learning in school or college, many people have learned new
skills on the job. It would help if the new skills were documented. 
An independent qualification authority was also proposed as a way of
improving consistency in grade levels across the Island; it would
also be a way of recognizing skills learned on the job, through on
line courses or even night classes.  







Other
ideas included offering
short technical courses to help young people get their first job
(three months was suggested) and then providing them with a voucher
to pay for further training after they get some experience.  Other
suggestions included vouchers covering costs of courses on an
employee’s own time even at night or on weekends. Traditional
report cards lack details about skills and levels learned. One remedy
is for institutions to follow the lead of PEI Workplace Learning in
giving each student a list of competencies on completion of a that
they can show to prospective employers.







These and other suggestions will be
forwarded by Education 20/20, host of the evet,  to booth Provincial
and federal authorities.

School engagement








A couple of months from now an Island school or learning centre will
receive a cheque for $2,500, and they can spend it for whatever they
want.  They will receive the award because of the nature and  extent

References the previous site at Wood Island where trees were planted in memory of Dr. Charles Keuper, a physician who came to PEI in 1979 and worked to protect and enhance the Island's natural beauty. Details that the Living Trust was established through Keuper family efforts to provide environmental enhancement and community memorialization. content_preview:
Draft Press Release for       , 2008




Living Memorial Trust Established




Islanders have another option when contributing to the Living Trust of The Community Foundation of Prince Edward  Island; the Foundation, in partnership with the Department of tourism, has designated Birch Crossing, Elmwood, PEI  as its planting site for 2008.  Space has ben set aside for planting a cluster of trees on each side of the entrance to The Confederation Trail  as well as sites for general planting and named trees.




This is the second in the Foundation’s designated sites; the other being theConfederation Trail entrance in Wood Island where, last year, a cluster of trees was planted on each side of the entrance to the Confederation Trail in memory of Dr. Charles Keuper.




The Living Trust was established through the efforts of the Keuper Family to remember the life of Dr. Charles Keuper, a physician who came to PEI after retirement in 1979 and worked tirelessly to protect and enhance the Island’s natural beauty.    




Living Memorials are more than just a tribute; living memorials enhance and beautify our environment, provide shelter for wild life, reduce erosion and improve the quality of the air we breathe.  Grants may be made for the enhancement of any public space, however, the initial focus will be on trail entrances.  




The Living Trust provides an opportunity for people to thank a friend, remember a relative, of mark a special occasion.  Individual interested in plantings in places of special significance should contact the Foundation.  Donors will be given a receipt to be used when filing Income Tax returns in Canada or the USA 




Persons interested in learning more about, or contributing to the Living Trust, may do so by contacting the Community Foundation office, 892-3440..

title: Program Review-2
summary: A revised January 2005 memo from Don to Ken (CFPEI Executive perspective), ccing Katy. Don reports the CFPEI Executive confirmed 2005 plans following JoAnn's secondment ending March 31 and Marla MacDonald's hiring as part-time office administrator. He frames the IAHSP mid-term review as appropriate timing given the program's completed selection process, institutional analysis of first candidates, signed agreements, and upcoming second round. Objectives: confirm program meets goals, identify challenges, identify operational improvements, and extract lessons for Round Two. Proposes simple external consultant review with standardized interviews of organizations, board, partners, and potentially unsuccessful applicants.
content_preview:
Draft




Date:		January 17, 2005




To:		Ken

Cc:		Katy




From:		Don




Subject:	IAHSP Review




In recent weeks I have become concerned about the implementation of the IAHSP.  Let me be more specific.




We are half way through the project; I think that we are well behind schedule

There is always a perception in projects such as this that the bulk of the money flows to administration and to consultants.  Because we have not yet flowed money to any of the organizations, this perception applies to IAHSP as well.

Our Board is bogged down in minutae; we need to see the big picture.  How will the project unfold during the remaining months?

Fairly early in November, I raised the matter of a second round fully expecting it to be dealt with at a November meeting.  It has not been addressed yet.

As the result of some conversations over the holiday season, there may be more unhappiness about the program than we realize.

I am not satisfied with the level and quality of reporting

We have not met our fund raising objective and I am not aware of any concrete plan to address the issue.




It is time for a in-depth mid-term review of the program.  I would like to have an external consultant report on :




The extent to which the program is meeting its objectives

If not, why not?

What changes, if any, are required to insure a successful program with the initial organizations?

What changes, if any, should be taken into account when implementing Round Two.

Dear 




This note is a brief follow-up to a conversation over coffee about estate planning and charitable giving.

It is commonly accepted that community foundations combine three main roles:




     1	      Endowment building and donor service	




Charitable gifts of many donors are pooled to create permanent, income-earning endowment funds – a nest egg that will always be there to benefit communities.  Community foundations connect donors with issues and organizations that matter most to them.  They offer a variety of funds to meet donors’ charitable goals and use their insight and experience to help donors have maximum impact.




Grantmaking  	




Income earned by invested funds is used to make grants to a wide range of community groups - and the original investment is left to grow.

title: Resignation
summary: A September 2005 resignation letter from Don to Ken Gillis (IAHSP Board Chair), ccing President of CFPEI John Robinson. Don cites two concerns: (1) the Board declined his recommendation to hire an external consultant for mid-term review, instead undertaking incomplete self-review; (2) on the day addressing additional six organizations, he abstained from voting due to lack of comfort with available information about Round One strengths/weaknesses. title: Roundtable
summary: A formal proposal for a one-day Literacy Roundtable convened by the Community Foundation to bring together practitioners, providers, and stakeholders for dialogue and information sharing. The invitational event would focus on "the interface between learner and teacher" and accommodate diverse providers. Participants would present concerns in succession without debate, followed by thematic discussion of topics including diagnosis, teaching methodologies, assessment, and reporting. The proposal emphasizes non-attributable discussion to encourage candor, with expected deliverables including scheduled follow-up discussions, fact sheets, and potentially a "Society for the Promotion of Literacy." This reflects Don's belief in the power of structured dialogue to overcome institutional silos.
content_preview:
Educ-Proposal-2

 Subject:	Literacy Roundtable




Background:	




Evidence abounds as to the importance of literacy for both our individual and community welfare.  Becoming literate is a very personal experience.  In PEI, responsibility for literacy lies with a number of agencies and organizations.  A couple of years ago, the Foundation was in touch with a number of providers and, while there is a wealth of information and services available, there appears to be little coordination or exchange of at the front line level.




The Foundation:




Community foundations, and thee are 170 in Canada today, are relatively new and unique part of the third sector in that they have a community focus, are committed to improving the quality of life in their community, act as hosts to individuals and organizations wishing to establish a trust,   Foundations also act as conveners of groups for the purpose of sharing information or solving problems.  This proposal is an example of the latter function.




Proposal:




The Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island proposes to convene a roundtable, for people intimately involved in the delivery of literacy education, for the purpose sharing information but also to identify gaps, if any, where the Foundation may be of service.




The roundtable will:

Be invitational

Be of one day’s duration

Focus on the interface between learner and teacher

Accommodate a wide spectrum of providers 

Be free to participants




Format:




Following opening remarks, each participant will be expected to speak briefly on some aspect or concern about literacy; this will be followed by an equally brief opportunity for questions or clarifications but not for debate.

Dear Shayne:




This is a follow-up to our telephone conversation of Friday, June 3.




As you know, community foundations are a new breed of charitable organization in Canada in that they are community based rather than cause based, and focus on carrying out a donor’s wishes.  Increasingly community foundations are becoming the vehicle of choice for people who wish to customize their legacies in the form of endowments.  Reasons why a donor should consider a community foundation are many including:

Continuity

Transparency and accountability

Low administration fee

Professional investment service

Maintenance of principal

Adaptive to changing circumstances

Flexibility

In the matter of scholarships, a community foundation based scholarship may be awarded to any student regardless of the institution chosen and, in fact, can follow a student from one institution to another on or off the Island.




Many donors have been active in their communities in a number of ways including making donations to their favourite charities; a community foundation can continue to make grants on their behalf in future years.  Other donors have interests that may not match mandates of existing organizations; a community foundation can develop a customized granting program to match those interests.  And in both cases, the interests guide granting decisions forever.   Because of our breadth of focus and Island-wide mandate, CFPEI is likely to be able to assist a donor in identifying community needs and designing an award to fit their interest.  Attention to donor wishes is provided in perpetuity and this service is provided at the ridiculously low administration fee rate of one percent of principal each year.

Dear Harry,




Thanks for seeing me on Thursday.  Given that I had left my file in the car, I decided to follow up with this note.




The Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island (CFPEI) is a volunteer driven, registered, non-profit, charitable organization.  Our mission is to improve the quality of life on PEI through the creation and building of endowment trust funds that will enhance life for all residents.  




The Foundation provides an established means for individuals, families, community groups, corporations, and private foundations to support philanthropic activities which invest in sustainable solutions to community needs.  We connect caring people and worthy causes through endowment building. 




For the past five years, CFPEI has organized a reception on July 4th for “Summer Islanders” who are US citizens.  The purpose is to give US citizens a venue to meet and celebrate their national day, to thank them for their contributions to our community and to keep them informed about the work of the Community Foundation.




The gathering is informal, with a cash bar, light food, a speaker, our national anthems, US flags and background music.  On three occasions, the US consul General from Halifax has joined us for the occasion.  Attendees are mostly US citizens with summer homes or who live here year round and contribute in so many ways to our Island life and Island economy.  Numbers usually range from 75 to 125 people.   




By means of this letter I am inviting Cooke Insurance to become a sponsor at the $250 level.
