title: YAC
summary: This document provides detailed analysis of Youth Advisory Committee (YAC) models used by community foundations across Canada, particularly the Fundy Foundation. It describes how YACs operate—student self-selection, monthly meetings, philanthropic needs assessment, local charity visits, and grant recommendations. The document outlines funding requirements ($2,500 for granting, $500 for expenses, $1,000 for overhead) and proposes CFPEI establish at least one YAC by September 2011 with a three-year commitment. It includes specific proposals for volunteer liaison positions and donor sponsorship recruitment.
content_preview:
Youth in Philanthropy (YIP)




Many community foundations operate YIP programs.  YIP’s are intended to provide opportunities for high school students to become involved in philanthropy and community development.  One model involves students in a single school; another model involves students in a community who may not all be from the same school.




Each year in September, a Youth Advisory Committee is established.  Students self select and run the show; it may be simply a club that meets at noon hour or after school.  Each YAC has an adult advisor selected by the youth.  In the case of the Fundy Foundation, the Exec Director also attends the meeting but that does not seem to be a requirement.  The YAC meets to explore philanthropic needs in their local are, especially needs of youth.  YACs discuss local needs, visit local charities, receive proposals/requests, conduct interviews, and present written recommendations to the grant-making committee of the community foundation. 

 

Once established the community foundation allocates a sum of money, $2,500 seems most common, which is distributed to local charities as recommended by the YAC.  Each Youth Advisory Committee is also expected to undertake fundraising for a Youth Endowment Fund which is a permanent endowment with the Foundation.  Earnings from the Fund are added each year to the Foundation grant thereby adding to the money available each year for distribution.




Fundy Foundation YAC has about 10 members, they come from different schools so meetings rotate, usually meet in the evening, often the Foundation provides pizza or sandwiches.  The YAC has co-leaders.  YAC members usually participate in the annual fund raising dinner.  Fundy Foundation says it is a popular activity and easy to find sponsors.

title: YIP-Press release
summary: Public announcement of the Youth in Philanthropy program launch, distributed by Jeniene Peake (Community Foundation contact). Announces the program target of youth ages 15-18, program components (monthly meetings studying community needs, organizational site visits, proposal solicitation and assessment, grant recommendations, endowment establishment), and first-year funding allocation ($1,000 grants per group, $500 endowment matching, administrative costs). Notes informal community interest and foundation's search for donors and sponsors, with program commencement at the beginning of school year 2011.
content_preview:
Youth in Philanthropy 




A Youth in Philanthropy (YIP) program is in the making at the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island.  The program is intended for young people between 15 and 18 years and will help them gain awareness of needs in their communities and to gain experience in dealing with philanthropic matters.




The program will be offered through schools and youth organizations and will include, monthly meetings to study philanthropic needs the local community, visits to local organizations, soliciting and assessing proposals for funds, recommending grants and establishing an endowment.




Each group will operate independently, although with an adult advisor, and will, in the first year, be allocated $1,000 to be given to one or more groups in their local community, up to $500 as a matching grant towards an endowment and a small amount of money to offset local administrative costs.




The Foundation has already broached the idea informally with schools and youth group leaders and there is an interest. The foundation is also looking for donors and sponsors.  The program will commence at the beginning of the school year in 2011.  




Further information is available from the Foundation at 892-3440
